Hello, my name is Alvin Ochieng. I am a mathematician working on a research program that requires formalizing some aspects of modern p-adic geometry in Lean 4. My work will involve defining objects related to the Fargues-Fontaine curve and p-adic Hodge theory. I plan to contribute these foundational libraries back to mathlib as they are developed.

My GitHub username is kunvoal. Could I please have permission to create branches on the mathlib4 repository so I can begin this work? Thank you.
The workflow has been changed, now you make PR's using your fork.

1. Fork the mathlib4 repo on GitHub
  2. on your terminal do git remote -v
  3. git remote add fork [url to your fork]
  4. git checkout -b [name of branch]
  5. write your code
  6. lake exe mk_all
  7. git add .
  8. git status
  9. git commit -am "commit message"
  10. Here's the important new step, git push -u fork [name of branch]
  11. And then PR using github
Welcome! See also the updated instructions at #contrib (and the git guide linked from there), if you haven't already.
@Alvin if I may ask, did you see the outdated information somewhere?
@Kenny Lau sorry a confusion my GitHub desktop write access was denied

@Alvin where are you going to start? I think that definition of an adic space is in scope. Regarding p-adic Hodge theory, we got Cp\mathbb{C}_pCp​ in mathlib this week and we are not too far from BdRB_{dR}BdR​ if you would like to join the effort. BcrisB_{cris}Bcris​ is further away though because it needs a robust theory of divided powers.
If you are having problems with git or github then can you please post the exact thing you typed/tried and the exact error that you got.
@Dagur Asgeirsson is working on adic spaces
cc @Chris Birkbeck @Jiang Jiedong @María Inés de Frutos Fernández who are all interested in p-adic Hodge theory/geometry

@Kevin Buzzard Thank you very much for the guidance, that's extremely helpful. My plan is to start with the most foundational algebraic objects first. Following your suggestion, I will begin by trying to formalize the ring of crystalline periods, B_cris, including its Q_p-algebra structure and the Frobenius endomorphism. My goal is to get that definition and its basic API correct before attempting the more complex de Rham period ring.
it brings me great joy to hear the word API here
For a definition of B_dR without proving any property, it is already on a PR of Mathlib waiting for ~5 PR’s before it.
The main ingredients before B_dR are the Fontaine’s theta map and the refactor of adic completion API.

In that case talking to @María Inés de Frutos Fernández and @Antoine Chambert-Loir is definitely a good idea since they are working on the divided powers stuff. They can also say how far they think we are from BcrisB_{\mathrm{cris}}Bcris​.
I think we don’t have the general theory of B-admissible representations now. That could be a good start for suitable API’s of p-adic Hodge theory.
Welcome, @Alvin ! I would not recommend starting with B_cris, because @Antoine Chambert-Loir and I are working towards it.

(@Jiang Jiedong don't forget that your PR has a conflict!)

The way to start this Alvin, if you're interested, is to post a potential definition of B-admissible representation (maybe in this thread) and then there will be a discussion about whether the definition is idiomatic. Once this is resolved, the fun starts because now you have to prove many basic theorems involving B-admissible representations (the API!) and here far less expert guidance is needed, it's something you can get on with yourself.

Looking forward to it!

@María Inés de Frutos Fernández Thank you so much for the warning! That is incredibly helpful, and you've saved me from duplicating your work. I will definitely not start with B_cris. Following the advice from this thread, I will pivot to looking at B-admissible representations instead. I'm very interested to follow your progress if you have a public branch or PR for the work on B_cris. Thanks again!

@Jiang Jiedong @Chris Birkbeck Thank you for pointing me to the existing PR for B_dR and the context about the Fontaine theta map and adic completion API. I will study that PR carefully to understand the established approach for these kinds of objects in mathlib.

@Kevin Buzzard Thank you, that is the perfect guidance and exactly what I was looking for. Proposing a definition for B-admissible representations sounds like a much better and more productive starting point.

I will begin by studying the literature to ensure I understand the nuances of the definition. My plan will then be to post a proposed structure definition here in this thread, as you suggested, to get feedback on whether it's idiomatic before I start proving the basic API for it. I really appreciate you pointing me in the right direction.
